definitions.definition: to be damaged and separated into two or more parts, as a result of force; to damage something in this way
definitions.sensetop: break in/into somethingbreak somethingbreak something in/into something
definitions.labels: (especially British English)(informal)(formal)(especially North American English)(British English)(especially British English)(North American English)(formal)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: All the windows broke with the force of the blast.
The bag broke under the weight of the bottles inside it.
She dropped the plate and it **broke into pieces**.
The boat hit a rock and **broke in half**.
to break a cup/window
She fell off a ladder and broke her arm.
to break a leg/bone
He **broke** the chocolate **in two**.
The glass broke into hundreds of pieces.
How did this dish get broken?
I didn't mean to break the window.
She broke the bar of chocolate in two and gave one half to me.

definitions.definition: to stop working as a result of being damaged; to damage something and stop it from working

examples.text: My watch has broken.
I think I've broken the washing machine.

definitions.definition: to cut the surface of the skin and make it bleed

examples.text: The dog bit me but didn't break the skin.

definitions.definition: to do something that is against the law; to not keep a promise, etc.

examples.text: I had **broken the law** and deserved to be punished.
People should not be allowed to **break the rules**.
to **break a promise**
to break an agreement/a contract/your word
to break an appointment *(= not to come to it)*
He was breaking the speed limit *(= travelling faster than the law allows)*.
They insist that they have not broken any rules.
Would you be willing to break the law to achieve your goal?
She had broken the conditions of her bail.
He has already broken three appointments.
Some companies have broken sanctions by supplying arms to the warring states.
I've never broken my word; why should I do it now?
Perhaps it is more courageous to break a promise if it means saving the economy.

definitions.definition: to stop doing something for a while, especially when it is time to eat or have a drink

examples.text: Let's **break for lunch**.
Parliament breaks for recess next week.
We broke early and went for a drink.
Their sleep was broken by noise from the street.
We broke our journey in Oxford *(= stopped in Oxford on the way to the place we were going to)*.

definitions.definition: to interrupt something so that it ends suddenly

examples.text: She **broke the silence** by coughing.
A tree **broke his fall** *(= stopped him as he was falling)*.
The phone rang and broke my train of thought.
Someone laughed suddenly and the spell was broken.

definitions.definition: to make something end by using force or strong action

examples.text: an attempt to break the year-long siege
Management has not succeeded in **breaking the strike**.

definitions.definition: to end a connection with something or a relationship with somebody

examples.text: He broke all ties with his parents.

definitions.definition: to manage to get away from or out of a position in which they have been caught

examples.text: He finally managed to break free from his attacker.

definitions.definition: to destroy something or make somebody/something weaker; to become weak or be destroyed

examples.text: to break somebody’s morale/resistance/resolve/spirit
The government was determined to break the power of the trade unions.
The scandal broke him *(= ruined his reputation and destroyed his confidence)*.
She broke under questioning *(= was no longer able to bear it)* and confessed to everything.

definitions.definition: to win a game in which it is your opponent's turn to serve (= hit the ball across the net first)

examples.text: Williams broke her opponent's serve five times.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel so sad, lonely, etc. that they cannot live a normal life

examples.text: The death of his wife broke him completely.

definitions.definition: to change suddenly, usually after a period when it has been fine

examples.text: On the third day the weather broke and they had a violent storm.

definitions.definition: to show an opening

examples.text: The clouds broke and the sun came out.

definitions.definition: to come up through the surface of water in the sea, a pool, etc.

examples.text: When his head broke the surface he took in deep gulps of air.

definitions.definition: when the day or dawn or a storm breaks, it begins

examples.text: Dawn was breaking when they finally left.

definitions.definition: if a piece of news breaks, it becomes known

examples.text: There was a public outcry when the scandal broke.

definitions.definition: to be the first to tell somebody some bad news

examples.text: Who's going to break it to her?
I'm sorry to be the one to break the news to you.
Just break the news to him gently.

definitions.definition: if somebody’s voice breaks, it changes its tone because of emotion

examples.text: Her voice broke as she told us what had happened.

definitions.definition: when a boy’s voice breaks, it becomes permanently deeper at about the age of 13 or 14
to do something better, faster, etc. than anyone has ever done it before

examples.text: She had broken the world 100 metres record.
The movie broke all box-office records.

definitions.definition: when waves break, they fall and are dissolved into foam, usually near land

examples.text: the sound of waves breaking on the beach
The sea was breaking over the wrecked ship.

definitions.definition: to find the meaning of something secret

examples.text: He needed only twenty minutes to break the encryption code.

definitions.definition: to change a banknote for coins

examples.text: Can you break a twenty-dollar bill?

wordOrigin: Old English brecan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch breken and German brechen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin frangere ‘to break’.
